Data Sources:


  1. Primary Rental Median Price 2024(Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation): https://www03.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/hmip-pimh/en/TableMapChart/Table?TableId=1.10.1&GeographyId=2410&GeographyTypeId=3&DisplayAs=Table&GeograghyName=Vancouver
  2. Child Care Map Data (OpenBC): https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca/dataset/child-care-map-data
  3. Metro Vancouver Shapefile (District of North Vancouver Open Data Portal): https://geoweb.dnv.org/data/
  4. Census Profile (Open Data Vancouver): https://opendata.vancouver.ca/explore/dataset/census-local-area-profiles-2016/information/
  5. BC Utility Bills (Primary Data compiled by MovingWaldo from Utility companies): https://www.movingwaldo.com/where-to-live/bc-utility-bills-how-much-does-utilities-cost/
  6. Consumer Price Index (BC Data Catalogue): https://catalogue.data.gov.bc.ca/dataset/2c75c627-3eb6-41ee-bb54-7b089eade484
  7. Vehicle Cost (BCAA): https://carcosts.caa.ca/results/british-columbia/suv_mainstream/ice?monthly_insurance_cost=0&monthly_car_payment=0
  8. Transit Cost (Translink): https://www.translink.ca/transit-fares/pricing-and-fare-zones
  9. Socioeconomic Data (Stats Canada): https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/pub/71-607-x/71-607-x2022004-eng.htm
  10. BC Tax Brackets (TurboTax): https://turbotax.intuit.ca/tax-resources/british-columbia-income-tax-calculator?srsltid=AfmBOopuGUtPADDlKm6oCvghMEEH5ig3TXOZDHiMMTRET9uKoqAIdUuh
  11. Groceries (Crowdsourced data from Numbeo): https://www.numbeo.com/food-prices/in/Vancouver
  12. Video: http://www.pexels.com

  1. Budgets and Financial Plans | Metro Vancouver: https://metrovancouver.org/about-us/budgets-and-financial-plans
  2. Support for Single Moms | YWCA Metro Vancouver: https://ywcavan.org/programs/support-single-moms
  3. Vancouver Affordability Guide: https://vancouvereconomic.com/affordability-guide/
  4. Free and low cost food programs — City of Vancouver Open Data Portal: https://opendata.vancouver.ca/explore/dataset/free-and-low-cost-food-programs/table/?sort=program_name
  5. $10 a Day ChildCareBC Centres by School Regions - Province of British Columbia: https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/family-social-supports/caring-for-young-children/childcarebc-programs/10-a-day-childcarebc-centres/10-a-day-centres-list

Redefining the Living Wage:


The living wage metric of the app was inspired by MIT’s Living Wage Calculator.


The metric is based on a 40 hour work week for the whole year (52 weeks).


Our living wage calculations contain the following factors:

  1. Median monthly rent cost, dependent on household type and city.
  2. Average monthly cost of transportation in Metro Vancouver, dependent on method of transportation (public, personal vehicle).
  3. Average cost of child care in Metro Vancouver (if the household has children).
  4. Average monthly cost of utilities in BC, taken as an average of all utilities.
  5. Average monthly cost of groceries per adult in Metro Vancouver (assuming a 2100 daily caloric intake).
  6. Average monthly cost of household items and personal hygiene in Metro Vancouver.
  7. Average monthly cost of internet and phone plans in BC Flat monthly cost of $100.
The future is AFFORDABLE and SUSTAINABLE with careful consideration!

What is MetroWage?


MetroWage, a living wage calculator for Metro Vancouver, aims to help people understand the cost of living across the metropolitan area by providing detailed, location-specific insights.


While the traditional "living wage" metric focuses on a two-adult, two-child household, our tool expands this by considering six distinct household types, different transportation options, and breaking down living costs for each municipality.


This geovisualization aims to give families and individuals a clearer view of affordability in different regions, supporting more informed decisions about where to live or rent.﻿

Why MetroWage?


Because the app is:


Family-focused: Highlights affordable and suitable living options for families in Metro Vancouver, using geographic data to visualize expenses.


Interactive: Engages users with dynamic widgets to deepen their understanding of living wage data.


Visually engaging: Transforms living wage information from static lists into geographic maps and customizable visualizations.


Insightful: Guides families and individuals in identifying regions that best align with their living expenses and needs.


Personalized: Features a "calculator" that adjusts to each user's financial situation, tailoring insights to their household setup.


Sustainable: Incorporates transportation choices—public transit or personal vehicle—into living cost calculations, highlighting potential savings and promoting eco-friendly alternatives.

How to Navigate MetroWage:


The top the page contains four navigation elements: Home, Calculator, Methodology, and Resources.

Each option corresponds to a page in our app, allowing you to easily navigate by clicking on the respective header.


Below are some summaries of what each page contains:


Home: The landing page you are currently at! This page contains the introduction and background information of the app, and provides everything you need to know to understand what this app is about.


Calculator: The page where the main portion of the app resides. The page itself contains a map to see the living wages required for each city and household type, as well as the calculator itself, situated right below the map. You can enter your estimated income in the calculator to see a list of the most budget-friendly cities for your household.


Methodology: This page explains the methods and justifications behind the calculation methods, and the data utilized in the app.


Resources: This page contains the sources used in the creation of this app, as well as any supporting resources that you may find useful for understanding the housing markets and financial landscapes of Metro Vancouver.

﻿Calculating the Living Wage:


We formalized the living wage calculations into an equation, to represent the monthly costs associated with each city, household type, and transportation method:

Calculating Income Tax and Affordability:'


The app contains an income tax calculator, that allows the user to input their yearly income or hourly wage (which would be scaled up to a yearly salary), to receive an estimate of their post-taxed yearly salary and/or hourly wage. The income taxation is modelled after the federal and provincial (BC) tax brackets shown on TurboTax’s 2024 tax calculator web page.


Using the determined net income representations from the income tax calculator, the “affordability” of each city is calculated by taking the difference between the user’s estimated hourly income and the living wage of each city. Any negative results from this operation are discarded, as they indicate the user cannot afford to live in the respective city. The remaining results are then ranked in descending order and displayed in the "Affordable Cities Ranked" section of the custom widget, showing the user their hourly savings for each city.

Where “L” is a living wage function of “h” (household type), “c” (city), and “t” (transportation mode) of the desired living wage parameters. “OtherCosts” represents the remaining costs associated with the living wage:﻿
…which can be represented as constants. We then utilized this equation to calculate the living wage associated with each combination of household type, city, and mode of transportation.

Justifying our Data:


Median Rent:

  1. Access to rental data consisted of different bedroom sizes for regions across Metro Vancouver.
  2. Median values in the data contained the most consistent and complete values meaning regions with any missing data could be accurately imputed.
  3. While data was available for neighbourhoods and cities, only the city data was used for consistency across the region.


Transportation:

  1. Costs for transportation were divided into two different categories of Transit or Car.
  2. Transit costs were derived from a Monthly-Fare pass that covered 1 zone.
  3. Households with Children concurred the Child Monthly-Fare pass for associated Children.
  4. The one zone fare was selected due to the zone sizes of the Metropolitan area covering wide ranges.
  5. Car costs were derived from the average cost of a 2024 Toyota Corolla Cross, taking into account gas, insurance, and repair costs.
  6. These features were selected to represent a cheaper car that can be associated with families or individuals.


Childcare Price and Accessibility:

  1. Childcare prices were gathered from a Westcoast Parent Services Survey for the Province of British Columbia and City of Vancouver.
  2. To calculate the cost used we took the average of the two medians of the categories of “Full Fee” and “Reduced Fee” to ensure a calculation that is more generalized for families using childcare.
  3. We looked into adding an accessibility component, which involved a 2km buffer of the 2,000+ childcare locations in Metro Vancouver, but found childcare accessibility was not an issue this calculation would focus on.


Utilities:

  1. Only regulated entities are permitted to sell and manage the distribution of utilities across the province.
  2. The average cost of water, gas, and electricity was used in the calculation.
  3. This gave a better representation of costs due to the varying price of electricity during times of high demand across the span of a day.


Groceries:

  1. Cost of groceries were taken from a crowdsourced website (NUMBEO citation) of general grocery items on a 2,100 calorie daily intake.
  2. Households with Children associated grocery costs of 75% of the adult grocery cost (based on calculations of average consumption of Children under the age of 13).


Household Items:

  1. Household and hygiene items were derived from a crowdsourced dataset (NUMBEO) from the Metropolitan Vancouver, where the average cost was taken for these categories.


Internet and Phone:

  1. Depending on the plan required by an individual the cost could vary.
  2. An average value was used for both internet and phone to reflect the price across BC.
  3. The Internet had the largest average fees derived from DSL, Cable, and Fibre Optic.
  4. $100 Flat Fee: The flat additional cost of $100 was to be associated with savings.
  5. Numbers associated on the internet suggest the average Canadian saves close to $100 per month.
